qas.question: What is the typical thickness of the epidermis?
What is the main function of the epidermis?
How much more thicker is the dermis to the epidermis?
What is the dermis mainly consist of?
What does the Hyperdermis consist of?
When the hypodermis is 10 to 30 cells thick, what is its main function?
What happens to the outermost cells of the hypodermis?
How do the bottommost cells of the hypodermis act?
How much thicker is the hypodermis from the dermis?
What are two components that make up the epidermis?

context: The epidermis is typically <a0_0>10 to 30 cells thick<a0_0/>; its main function is <a1_0><b5_0>to provide a waterproof layer<b5_0/><a1_0/>. Its outermost cells are <b6_0>constantly lost<b6_0/>; its bottommost cells are <b7_0>constantly dividing and pushing upward<b7_0/>. The middle layer, the dermis, is <a2_0><b8_0>15 to 40 times thicker<b8_0/><a2_0/> than the epidermis. The dermis is made up of many components, such as <a3_0><b9_0>bony structures and blood vessels<b9_0/><a3_0/>. The hypodermis is made up of <a4_0>adipose tissue<a4_0/>. Its job is to store lipids, and to provide cushioning and insulation. The thickness of this layer varies widely from species to species.
